The Mobius Group

Mo¨\ddot oo¨bius transformations

(The ooo with an umlaut is not to be confused with the second derivative of ooo.)

Definition. The Möbius map f:C→Cf: \mathbb{C \to C}f:C→C is defined as f(z)=az+bcz+df(z) = \frac{az+b}{cz+d}f(z)=cz+daz+b​ for a,b,c,d∈Ca, b, c, d\in \mathbb{C}a,b,c,d∈C, ad−bc≠0ad - bc \neq 0ad−bc=0. (If ad−bc=0ad-bc = 0ad−bc=0, then we would have

z,w∈C, f(z)−f(w)=az+bcz+d−aw+bcw+d=(az+b)(cw+d)−(aw+b)(cz+d)(cz+d)(cw+d)=adz+bcw−adw−bcz(cz+d)(cw+d)=(ad−bc)(z−w)(cz+d)(cw+d)=0 if ad−bc=0\begin{aligned} z,w \in \mathbb{C},\ f(z)-f(w) &= \frac{az+b}{cz+d}-\frac{aw+b}{cw+d} \\ &= \frac{(az+b)(cw+d)-(aw+b)(cz+d)}{(cz+d)(cw+d)} \\ &= \frac{adz + bcw - adw - bcz}{(cz+d)(cw+d)} \\ &= \frac{(ad-bc)(z-w)}{(cz+d)(cw+d)} \\ &= 0\text{ if }ad-bc=0 \end{aligned}z,w∈C, f(z)−f(w)​=cz+daz+b​−cw+daw+b​=(cz+d)(cw+d)(az+b)(cw+d)−(aw+b)(cz+d)​=(cz+d)(cw+d)adz+bcw−adw−bcz​=(cz+d)(cw+d)(ad−bc)(z−w)​=0 if ad−bc=0​

which is discarded for committing the cardinal sin of being too boring.)

Definition. The Riemann sphere. (This sounds like a pokeball used to catch mathematicians or something.) The extension of the complex plane via the introduction of an "infinity element" - C∪{∞}\mathbb{C} \cup \{\infty\}C∪{∞} - is known as the Riemann sphere, denoted by C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^.

The Möbius map defined above is only well-defined everywhere in the Riemann sphere and not in C\mathbb{C}C, as f(−dc)f(-\frac{d}{c})f(−cd​) would result in division by zero; we circumvent this by giving it the middle finger and saying "dividing by zero is okay as long as we assign a fancy symbol to it, cover it in white cloth and never attempt to make eye contact with what comes out the other end", i.e. f(−dc)=∞f(-\frac{d}{c}) = \inftyf(−cd​)=∞ where ∞\infty∞ is not to be treated as some mystical, impenetrable monument of math, but a number we can do calculations with. Similarly, we define f(∞)=lim⁡z→∞f(z)=acf(\infty) = \lim_{z\to \infty} f(z) = \frac{a}{c}f(∞)=limz→∞​f(z)=ca​.

Proposition. Extension of the Möbius map to C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^. (Guess how many times I've had to search up "copy o with an umlaut to clipboard" by now.) The Möbius map is well-defined everywhere in the Riemann sphere, with the following values being specially defined:

  1. f(∞)=lim⁡z→∞az+bcz+d=acf(\infty) = \lim_{z\to\infty}\frac{az+b}{cz+d} = \frac{a}{c}f(∞)=limz→∞​cz+daz+b​=ca​.
  2. f(−dc)=∞f(-\frac{d}{c}) = \inftyf(−cd​)=∞.
  3. f(∞)=∞f(\infty) = \inftyf(∞)=∞ when c=0c = 0c=0 (derived from the first two definitions).

    (Even though we have defined these special conventions, the notation az+bcz+d\frac{az+b}{cz+d}cz+daz+b​ will still be used interchangeably with fff with the understanding that the above properties hold only for the Möbius map as we have defined it.)

One last point to wrangle with a little bit: why is the Riemann sphere called a sphere when, as far as we know, there are no spheres visible anywhere to the naked eye? First off, Riemann must have had some really small spheres when viewed naked viewed through the naked eye; but second of all, consider a unit sphere centered about the origin -

S2={(x,y,z)∈R:x2+y2+z2=1}S_2 = \{(x,y,z) \in \mathbb{R}: x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 1\}S2​={(x,y,z)∈R:x2+y2+z2=1}

Suppose you're standing at the very top of this sphere - the point (0,0,1)(0,0,1)(0,0,1), the north pole of the sphere - and that the complex plane (which we will consider the xyxyxy-plane) is sitting at the equator of this sphere. If you angle your field of vision in a particular direction - for instance, through a point ppp on the sphere - is it possible to see any possible point on the complex plane?

The answer is yes; for every point r(p)r(p)r(p) on the complex plane, a line can be drawn through the north pole to a general point ppp on the sphere, and this point ppp is uniquely determined by r(p)r(p)r(p), with there only being one possible line through

(r(p)x,r(p)y,0)→(0,0,1)(r(p)_x, r(p)_y, 0) \to (0,0,1)(r(p)x​,r(p)y​,0)→(0,0,1)

which will only intersect the sphere at one point, and vice versa, with ∞\infty∞ being ampped to the point (0,0,1)(0,0,1)(0,0,1). I suppose this explanation for why a sphere is actually a plane does motivate the study of Möbius maps a bit, but it only considers the top half of the sphere - it's a little one-sided. (Get it? Because the Möbius strip has only one side? HA HA HA HA HA HA HA - i'll see myself out bye)

(This technique is called stereographic projection, and is used to convert a globe of the Earth into flat maps. This means that the Earth is actually neither flat nor round, but is instead a secret third thing that exists as a bijection between the flat earthers and the globalists.)

Group properties of the Möbius map

As Möbius famously said when referring to himself, "persons who have a decided mathematical talent constitute a superior class to everyone else." Bold words for someone whose most lasting contribution to mankind is a strip of paper that looks like it was chewed on by a 5-year-old.

A brief TL;DR - why study Möbius maps? Because Möbius maps are bijections from the Riemann sphere to itself, and because of that, Möbius maps are invertible and form a group; and because of that, Möbius maps are a group action on the Riemann sphere (the extended complex plane) that turn out to be the only group actions that preserve properties like angles and structures like circles.

The Möbius maps form a group

Lemma. Möbius maps form a bijection from C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^ to C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^.

Proof.

As previously defined, the Möbius map takes the entirety of C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^ as its domain; we need only prove that the map is invertible. Denote the inverse of the Möbius map as y=f−1(z)y=f^{-1}(z)y=f−1(z); then we have

f(y)=zay+bcy+d=zay+b=czy+dz(a−cz)y=dz−by=dz−ba−cz\begin{aligned} f(y) &= z \\ \frac{ay + b}{cy + d} &= z \\ ay + b &= czy + dz \\ (a-cz)y &= dz - b \\ y &= \frac{dz-b}{a-cz} \end{aligned}f(y)cy+day+b​ay+b(a−cz)yy​=z=z=czy+dz=dz−b=a−czdz−b​​

which is again a Möbius map and can be verified to be the inverse of fff.

Proposition. Let MMM be the set of all Möbius maps (or, if you like, the set of matrices M=[abcd]M = \begin{bmatrix} a&b \\c&d\end{bmatrix}M=[ac​bd​] that map - not one-to-one! - onto f(z)=az+bcz+df(z) =\frac{az+b}{cz+d}f(z)=cz+daz+b​, with ad−bc=det⁡M≠0ad-bc = \det M \neq 0ad−bc=detM=0.) Then MMM forms a group under function composition.

Side note: the group of all matrices with det⁡M≠0\det M \neq 0detM=0 is simply GL2GL_2GL2​, so we are done! (Actually, we're not - we'll see later that these two groups aren't isomorphic.) But alas, the alluring sway of masochism compels us once again to deliver a

Proof.

  1. Closure. This one is a pain. Let f(z)=a1z+b1c1z+d1f(z) = \frac{a_1 z + b_1}{c_1 z + d_1}f(z)=c1​z+d1​a1​z+b1​​ and g(z)=a2z+b2c2z+d2g(z) = \frac{a_2 z + b_2}{c_2 z + d_2}g(z)=c2​z+d2​a2​z+b2​​ both be elements of MMM, with a1d1−b1d1≠0a_1d_1 - b_1d_1 \neq 0a1​d1​−b1​d1​=0 and a2d2−b2c2≠0a_2d_2 - b_2c_2 \neq 0a2​d2​−b2​c2​=0. Then we have
    f(g(z))=a1(a2z+b2c2z+d2)+b1c1(a2z+b2c2z+d2)+d1=a1a2z+a1b2+b1c2z+b1d2c1a2z+c1b2+d1c2z+d1d2=(a1a2+b1c2)z+(a1b2+b1d2)(c1a2+d1c2)z+(c1b2+d1d2)\begin{aligned} f(g(z)) &= \frac{a_1 (\frac{a_2 z + b_2}{c_2 z + d_2}) + b_1 }{c_1 (\frac{a_2 z + b_2}{c_2 z + d_2}) + d_1} \\ &= \frac{a_1a_2z + a_1b_2 + b_1c_2z + b_1d_2}{c_1a_2z + c_1b_2 + d_1c_2z + d_1d_2} \\ &= \frac{(a_1a_2 + b_1c_2)z + (a_1b_2+b_1d_2)}{(c_1a_2 + d_1c_2)z + (c_1b_2+d_1d_2)} \end{aligned}f(g(z))​=c1​(c2​z+d2​a2​z+b2​​)+d1​a1​(c2​z+d2​a2​z+b2​​)+b1​​=c1​a2​z+c1​b2​+d1​c2​z+d1​d2​a1​a2​z+a1​b2​+b1​c2​z+b1​d2​​=(c1​a2​+d1​c2​)z+(c1​b2​+d1​d2​)(a1​a2​+b1​c2​)z+(a1​b2​+b1​d2​)​​
    which is again an element of MMM, as we have
    (a1a2+b1c2)(c1b2+d1d2)−(a1b2+b1d2)(c1a2+d1c2)=a1a2d1d2+b1c2c1b2−a1b2d1c2−b1d2c1a2=b1c1(c2b2−d2a2)+a1d1(a2d2−b2c2)=(a2d2−b2c2)(a1d1−b1c1)≠0.\begin{aligned} (a_1a_2 + b_1c_2)(c_1b_2 + d_1d_2) - (a_1b_2 + b_1d_2)(c_1a_2 + d_1c_2) \\ = a_1a_2d_1d_2 + b_1c_2c_1b_2 - a_1b_2d_1c_2 - b_1d_2c_1a_2 \\ = b_1c_1(c_2b_2 - d_2a_2) + a_1d_1(a_2d_2 - b_2c_2) \\ = (a_2 d_2 - b_2 c_2)(a_1 d_1 - b_1 c_1) \neq 0. \end{aligned}(a1​a2​+b1​c2​)(c1​b2​+d1​d2​)−(a1​b2​+b1​d2​)(c1​a2​+d1​c2​)=a1​a2​d1​d2​+b1​c2​c1​b2​−a1​b2​d1​c2​−b1​d2​c1​a2​=b1​c1​(c2​b2​−d2​a2​)+a1​d1​(a2​d2​−b2​c2​)=(a2​d2​−b2​c2​)(a1​d1​−b1​c1​)=0.​
  2. Identity. We simply have 1(z)=z1(z) = z1(z)=z as the identity under function composition.
  3. Inverse. The Möbius map is invertible, as shown above, and its inverse is another Möbius map.
  4. Association is inherited from function composition.

Lemma. We mentioned earlier that GL2GL_2GL2​ has some relationship to MMM; and indeed, with every matrix A=[abcd]A = \begin{bmatrix} a&b \\c&d\end{bmatrix}A=[ac​bd​] we could define a function ϕ\phiϕ mapping from AAA to a Möbius map in MMM, like so -

ϕ(A)=az+bcz+d.\phi(A) = \frac{az + b}{cz +d}.ϕ(A)=cz+daz+b​.

However, such a function is not one-to-one: ϕ(λA)=ϕ(λ)\phi(\lambda A) = \phi(\lambda)ϕ(λA)=ϕ(λ) for any constant λ\lambdaλ. Thus, ϕ\phiϕ is a homomorphism rather than an isomorphism between GL2(C)→MGL_2(\mathbb{C}) \to MGL2​(C)→M.

Proof.

For two matrices A=[a1b1c1d1]A = \begin{bmatrix} a_1&b_1 \\c_1&d_1\end{bmatrix}A=[a1​c1​​b1​d1​​] and B=[a2b2c2d2]B = \begin{bmatrix} a_2&b_2 \\c_2&d_2\end{bmatrix}B=[a2​c2​​b2​d2​​] in GL2(C)GL_2(\mathbb{C})GL2​(C) (i.e. nonzero determinant), we have

ϕ(A)∘Mϕ(B)=(a1a2+b1c2)z+(a1b2+b1d2)(c1a2+d1c2)z+(c1b2+d1d2)\phi(A) \circ_M \phi(B) = \frac{(a_1a_2 + b_1c_2)z + (a_1b_2+b_1d_2)}{(c_1a_2 + d_1c_2)z + (c_1b_2+d_1d_2)}ϕ(A)∘M​ϕ(B)=(c1​a2​+d1​c2​)z+(c1​b2​+d1​d2​)(a1​a2​+b1​c2​)z+(a1​b2​+b1​d2​)​

as shown above, and

AB=[a1a2+b1c2a1b2+b1d2c1a2+d1c2c1b2+d1d2]AB = \begin{bmatrix} a_1 a_2 + b_1 c_2 & a_1 b_2 + b_1 d_2 \\ c_1 a_2 + d_1 c_2 & c_1 b_2 + d_1 d_2 \end{bmatrix}AB=[a1​a2​+b1​c2​c1​a2​+d1​c2​​a1​b2​+b1​d2​c1​b2​+d1​d2​​]

corresponding to the above Möbius map, as desired. This homomorphism is surjective, because for any Möbius map a matrix formed out of its coefficients can be constructed (not necessarily uniquely); its kernel is the group of multiples of the identity matrix Z={λI:λ∈C,λ≠0}Z= \{\lambda I: \lambda \in \mathbb{C}, \lambda \neq 0\}Z={λI:λ∈C,λ=0}, with the First Isomorphism Theorem giving M≅GL2(C)/ZM \cong GL_2(\mathbb{C})/ZM≅GL2​(C)/Z.

Lemma. All Möbius maps can be writte as a finite composition of the following simple Möbius maps, in some order and potentially with repeats:

  1. The enlargement/dilation/rotation map, f(z)=azf(z) = azf(z)=az for some a∈Ca \in \mathbb{C}a∈C.
  2. The translation map, f(z)=z+bf(z) = z + bf(z)=z+b for b∈Cb \in \mathbb{C}b∈C.
  3. The inversion map, f(z)=1zf(z) = \frac{1}{z}f(z)=z1​.

Proof.

The general form of a Möbius map is f(z)=az+bcz+df(z) = \frac{az+b}{cz+d}f(z)=cz+daz+b​. f(∞)=∞f(\infty) = \inftyf(∞)=∞ if and only if c=0c = 0c=0; when c=0c=0c=0, we have

f(z)=az+bd=adz+bdf(z) = \frac{az+b}{d} = \frac{a}{d}z + \frac{b}{d}f(z)=daz+b​=da​z+db​

which is clearly a dilation by ad\frac{a}{d}da​ combined with a translation by bd\frac{b}{d}db​. If instead c≠0c\neq 0c=0, let f(∞)=z0f(\infty) = z_0f(∞)=z0​; then the following construction

h(f(z))=1f(z)−z0, h(f(∞))=1z0−z0=∞h(f(z)) = \frac{1}{f(z)-z_0},\ h(f(\infty))=\frac{1}{z_0-z_0} = \inftyh(f(z))=f(z)−z0​1​, h(f(∞))=z0​−z0​1​=∞

has h(f(z))∈Mh(f(z)) \in Mh(f(z))∈M due to closure, and h(f(z))=g(z)h(f(z)) = g(z)h(f(z))=g(z) being a Möbius map with c=0c=0c=0 due to the first statement. We know that a Möbius map g(z)g(z)g(z) with c=0c=0c=0 is composed of (at most) two simple Möbius maps, a dilation and a translation; thus we have

f(z)=h−1(g(z))f(z) = h^{-1}(g(z))f(z)=h−1(g(z))

where h−1(z)=1z+z0h^{-1}(z) = \frac{1}{z} + z_0h−1(z)=z1​+z0​, and is thus composed of an inversion plus a translation. Therefore, any f(z)f(z)f(z) is composed of the above three simple Möbius maps.

Fixed points of Möbius maps

Definition. A fixed point of a Möbius map fff is a complex number z∈Cz \in \mathbb{C}z∈C such that f(z)=zf(z) = zf(z)=z.

Proposition. If a Möbius map has three or more fixed points, it is the identity f(z)=zf(z) = zf(z)=z.

Proof.

A fixed point of a Möbius map is equivalent to a complex root of the quadratic equation

f(z)=az+bcz+d=z, cz2+(d−a)z−b=0f(z) = \frac{az + b}{cz + d} = z,\ cz^2 +(d-a)z -b =0f(z)=cz+daz+b​=z, cz2+(d−a)z−b=0

which has at most two complex roots by the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, unless the left-hand side is identically zero, in which case c=0c= 0c=0, d=ad=ad=a and b=0b =0b=0 yielding f(z)=aza=zf(z) = \frac{az}{a} = zf(z)=aaz​=z. (This is what mathematicians call "nuking an anthill.")

Proposition. Any Möbius map is conjugate under function composition to either a dilation f(z)=νzf(z) = \nu zf(z)=νz or the simple translation f(z)=z+1f(z) = z +1f(z)=z+1.

Proof.

As shown above, the general linear group of 2×22\times 22×2 complex matries GL2(C)GL_2(\mathbb{C})GL2​(C) is surjectively homomorphic to the group of Möbius maps MMM. For this surjective homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ, we have

A,B,P∈GL2(C), PAP−1=BA, B, P \in GL_2(\mathbb{C}),\ PAP^{-1} = BA,B,P∈GL2​(C), PAP−1=B

implying

ϕ(PAP−1)=ϕ(P)∘ϕ(A)∘ϕ(P−1)=ϕ(B)\phi(PAP^{-1}) = \phi(P)\circ \phi(A)\circ \phi(P^{-1}) = \phi(B)ϕ(PAP−1)=ϕ(P)∘ϕ(A)∘ϕ(P−1)=ϕ(B)

and as such ϕ(A)\phi(A)ϕ(A) and ϕ(B)\phi(B)ϕ(B) are conjugates in MMM. As the conjugacy classes partition GL2(C)GL_2(\mathbb{C})GL2​(C) and GL2(C)GL_2(\mathbb{C})GL2​(C) map surjectively onto MMM via ϕ\phiϕ, the conjugacy classes of GL2(C)GL_2(\mathbb{C})GL2​(C) completely describe the conjugacy classes of MMM.

From Canonical Forms we know that the conjugacy classes of GL2(C)GL_2(\mathbb{C})GL2​(C) are of the following three types: [λ00λ]\begin{bmatrix}\lambda & 0 \\ 0 &\lambda \end{bmatrix}[λ0​0λ​], [λ00μ]\begin{bmatrix}\lambda & 0 \\ 0 &\mu \end{bmatrix}[λ0​0μ​], and [λ10λ]\begin{bmatrix}\lambda & 1 \\ 0 &\lambda \end{bmatrix}[λ0​1λ​] for λ,μ∈C\lambda, \mu \in \mathbb{C}λ,μ∈C. Applying the homomorphism above gives us the Möbius maps

{λz+00+λ=z=1z,λz+00+μ=λμz,λz+1λ=z+1λ\begin{cases} \frac{\lambda z + 0}{0 + \lambda} = z = 1z, \\ \frac{\lambda z + 0}{0 + \mu} = \frac{\lambda}{\mu} z,\\ \frac{\lambda z + 1}{\lambda} = z + \frac{1}{\lambda} \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​0+λλz+0​=z=1z,0+μλz+0​=μλ​z,λλz+1​=z+λ1​​

where the final matrix [λ10λ]\begin{bmatrix}\lambda & 1 \\ 0 &\lambda \end{bmatrix}[λ0​1λ​] can be rewritten [11λ01]\begin{bmatrix}1 & \frac{1}{\lambda} \\ 0 &1 \end{bmatrix}[10​λ1​1​], giving us f(z)=z+1f(z) = z+1f(z)=z+1. □\square□

Lemma. A Möbius map fff has a fixed point zzz if and only if its conjugate gfg−1gfg^{-1}gfg−1 for some g∈Mg \in Mg∈M has a fixed point g(z)g(z)g(z); as such, all non-identity Möbius maps have either 111 fixed point (if conjugate to f(z)=z+1f(z) = z+1f(z)=z+1) or 222 fixed points (if conjugate to f(z)=νzf(z)=\nu zf(z)=νz).

Proof.

The first statement can be demonstrated directly via

f(z)=z  ⟹  gfg−1(g(z))=gf(g−1(g(z)))=gf(z)=g(z)f(z) = z \implies gfg^{-1}(g(z)) = gf(g^{-1}(g(z))) = gf(z) = g(z)f(z)=z⟹gfg−1(g(z))=gf(g−1(g(z)))=gf(z)=g(z)

and as such g(z)g(z)g(z) is a fixed point of gfg−1gfg^{-1}gfg−1; conversely

gfg−1(g(z))=g(z)  ⟹  gf(z)=g(z)  ⟹  f(z)=z.gfg^{-1}(g(z)) = g(z) \implies gf(z) = g(z) \implies f(z) = z.gfg−1(g(z))=g(z)⟹gf(z)=g(z)⟹f(z)=z.

Thus, if a Möbius map f∈Mf \in Mf∈M is conjugate to f(z)=νzf(z) = \nu zf(z)=νz; this fixes 000 and ∞\infty∞ only, and thus fff has two fixed points. Alternatively, if f∈Mf \in Mf∈M is conjugate to f(z)=z+1f(z) = z+1f(z)=z+1, then this fixes z=∞z= \inftyz=∞ only and thus fff has only one fixed point.

Group actions of Möbius maps

Proposition. The group of Möbius maps acts faithfully and transitively on the Riemann sphere C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^ through f∈M,z∈C^:ϕ(f,z)=f(z)f \in M, z\in \mathbb{\hat C}: \phi(f,z) = f(z)f∈M,z∈C^:ϕ(f,z)=f(z).

Proof.

Check the three properties of a group action:

  1. Identity: we have 1(z)=z1(z) = z1(z)=z as the identity of MMM, and ϕ(1(z),z)=z\phi(1(z), z) = zϕ(1(z),z)=z for all z∈C^z \in \mathbb{\hat C}z∈C^.

  2. Closure: all Möbius maps map from C^→C^\mathbb{\hat C}\to \mathbb{\hat C}C^→C^ bijectively, and thus for all z1,z2∈C^z_1, z_2 \in \mathbb{\hat C}z1​,z2​∈C^ we have

    f(z)=z+z2−z1, f(z1)=z2f(z) = z + z_2 - z_1,\ f(z_1) = z_2f(z)=z+z2​−z1​, f(z1​)=z2​

    demonstrating transitivity, as well as

    ∀z, f(z)=z\forall z,\ f(z) = z∀z, f(z)=z

    implying that fff is the identity by default.

  3. Associativity: true by definition of function composition.

In fact, it is not only true that for any pair of points z1z_1z1​ and z2z_2z2​ we can find (often an infinite number) of Möbius maps that send z1z_1z1​ to z2z_2z2​; we have a far stronger result as follows.

Definition. Call a group action ϕ\phiϕ of GGG on XXX three-transitive if for any two triples (x1,x2,x3)(x_1, x_2, x_3)(x1​,x2​,x3​) and (y1,y2,y3)(y_1, y_2, y_3)(y1​,y2​,y3​), all in XXX, we have some g∈Gg\in Gg∈G such that g(x1)=y1g(x_1)=y_1g(x1​)=y1​, g(x2)=y2g(x_2)=y_2g(x2​)=y2​ and g(x3)=y3g(x_3) = y_3g(x3​)=y3​ - that is to say, an element exists that sends any triplet to another arbitrary triplet under this group action. If this g∈Gg\in Gg∈G is unique, call the group action sharply three-transitive.

Proposition. MMM acts sharply three-transitively on C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^.

Proof.

The statement is true as long as we can show that there exists a Möbius map which maps any three points (x1,x2,x3)(x_1, x_2, x_3)(x1​,x2​,x3​) in C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^ to (0,1,∞)(0, 1, \infty)(0,1,∞) - the special points of the Möbius map - and that there exists a Möbius map which maps these three points to any (y1,y2,y3)(y_1, y_2, y_3)(y1​,y2​,y3​).

For the first such Möbius map, consider

f(z)=(z−x1)(x2−x3)(z−x3)(x2−x1)f(z) = \frac{(z-x_1)(x_2-x_3)}{(z-x_3)(x_2-x_1)}f(z)=(z−x3​)(x2​−x1​)(z−x1​)(x2​−x3​)​

which maps x1→0x_1 \to 0x1​→0, x2→1x_2 \to 1x2​→1, x3→∞x_3 \to \inftyx3​→∞. For the second, the Möbius map

g(z)=(z−y1)(y2−y3)(z−y3)(y2−y1)g(z) = \frac{(z-y_1)(y_2-y_3)}{(z-y_3)(y_2-y_1)}g(z)=(z−y3​)(y2​−y1​)(z−y1​)(y2​−y3​)​

maps y1→0y_1 \to 0y1​→0, y2→1y_2 \to 1y2​→1 and y3→∞y_3 \to \inftyy3​→∞ instead; as such, g−1(z)g^{-1}(z)g−1(z) will map 0→y10 \to y_10→y1​, 1→y21 \to y_21→y2​, and ∞→y3\infty \to y_3∞→y3​, and so g−1f(z)g^{-1}f(z)g−1f(z) satisfies our condition. We know that this function is unique because

Lemma. Any Möbius map f∈Mf \in Mf∈M is uniquely determined by three points; if f(zi)=g(zi)f(z_i)=g(z_i)f(zi​)=g(zi​) for i=1,2,3i = 1, 2, 3i=1,2,3, then f=gf = gf=g. This can be directly shown via fg−1(zi)=zifg^{-1}(z_i) = z_ifg−1(zi​)=zi​, leading to three fixed points for the Möbius map fg−1fg^{-1}fg−1 and thus leading to fg−1fg^{-1}fg−1 being the identity.

This verifies that MMM acts sharply three-transitively on C\mathbb{C}C. □\square□

Möbius maps preserve geometric structures

Lemma. Both circles and lines in the complex plane can be generally represented by the locus of complex numbers zzz such that

Azzˉ+Bˉz+Bzˉ+C=0Az\bar z + \bar B z + B \bar z + C = 0Azzˉ+Bˉz+Bzˉ+C=0

where A,C∈RA, C \in \mathbb{R}A,C∈R, B∈CB \in \mathbb{C}B∈C, and ∣B∣2>AC|B|^2 > AC∣B∣2>AC; A=0A=0A=0 gives a straight line, while A≠0A \neq 0A=0 gives a circle.

Proof.

We know that the complex-number representation of a circle centered at a point BBB with radius rrr is

∣z−B∣=r|z-B| = r∣z−B∣=r

which can be equivalently written as

∣z−B∣2=(z−B)(z−B)‾=r2|z-B|^2 = (z-B)\overline{(z-B)} = r^2∣z−B∣2=(z−B)(z−B)​=r2

as ∣z−B∣|z-B|∣z−B∣ is always non-negative. This yields

(z−B)(zˉ−Bˉ)=r2zzˉ−zBˉ−Bzˉ−BBˉ=r2zzˉ−Bˉz−Bzˉ−(BBˉ+r2)=0\begin{aligned} (z-B)(\bar z - \bar B) &= r^2 \\ z\bar z - z \bar B - B \bar z - B \bar B &= r^2 \\ z\bar z - \bar B z - B\bar z - (B\bar B + r^2) &= 0 \end{aligned}(z−B)(zˉ−Bˉ)zzˉ−zBˉ−Bzˉ−BBˉzzˉ−Bˉz−Bzˉ−(BBˉ+r2)​=r2=r2=0​

which corresponds to the given form, as BBˉB\bar BBBˉ and r2r^2r2 are both real.

On the other hand, the locus of all complex numbers that form a line which perpendicularly bisects the line segment between aaa and bbb can be written

∣z−a∣=∣z−b∣|z-a| = |z-b|∣z−a∣=∣z−b∣

or

(z−a)(zˉ−aˉ)=(z−b)(zˉ−aˉ)(z-a)(\bar z - \bar a) = (z-b)(\bar z - \bar a)(z−a)(zˉ−aˉ)=(z−b)(zˉ−aˉ)

which reduces to the form above, with the zzˉz\bar zzzˉ term cancelling out.

Theorem. A Möbius map maps any circle or line in the complex plane to another circle or line in the complex plane (not necessarily respectively, i.e. circles can be mapped to lines, and vice versa).

Proof.

Any Möbius map is a composition of the three elementary Möbius maps: a dilation f(z)=νzf(z) = \nu zf(z)=νz, a translation f(z)=z+af(z) = z + af(z)=z+a, and an inversion f(z)=1zf(z) = \frac{1}{z}f(z)=z1​. As such, we only need to show that all three maps preserve the equation

Azzˉ+Bˉz+Bzˉ+C=0.Az\bar z + \bar B z + B \bar z + C = 0.Azzˉ+Bˉz+Bzˉ+C=0.

For a dilation: z→νzz \to \nu zz→νz gives

Aνzˉ+Bˉνz+Bνˉzˉ+C=0A\nu\bar z + \bar B \nu z + B\bar \nu \bar z + C = 0Aνzˉ+Bˉνz+Bνˉzˉ+C=0

which is still in the required form, as (Bˉν)‾=Bνˉ\overline{(\bar B \nu)} = B \bar \nu(Bˉν)​=Bνˉ.

For a translation: z→z+az \to z + az→z+a gives

A(z+a)(zˉ+aˉ)+Bˉ(z+a)+B(zˉ+aˉ)+C=A(zzˉ+aˉz+azˉ+aaˉ)+Bˉz+Bˉa+Bzˉ+Baˉ+C=Azzˉ+(Aaˉ+Bˉ)z+(Aa+B)zˉ+(Aaaˉ+Bˉa+Baˉ+C)\begin{aligned} A(z+a)(\bar z + \bar a) + \bar B (z+a) + B (\bar z + \bar a) + C \\ = A(z\bar z + \bar a z + a \bar z + a \bar a) + \bar Bz + \bar Ba + B\bar z + B \bar a + C \\ = Az \bar z + (A\bar a + \bar B)z + (Aa + B)\bar z + (Aa\bar a + \bar B a + B \bar a + C) \end{aligned}A(z+a)(zˉ+aˉ)+Bˉ(z+a)+B(zˉ+aˉ)+C=A(zzˉ+aˉz+azˉ+aaˉ)+Bˉz+Bˉa+Bzˉ+Baˉ+C=Azzˉ+(Aaˉ+Bˉ)z+(Aa+B)zˉ+(Aaaˉ+Bˉa+Baˉ+C)​

which corresponds to the form above because (Aaˉ+Bˉ)‾=Aa+B\overline{(A\bar a + \bar B)} = Aa + B(Aaˉ+Bˉ)​=Aa+B, from AAA being real and thus Aˉ=A\bar A = AAˉ=A.

Finally, for an inversion z→1zz \to \frac{1}{z}z→z1​ we have

A1zzˉ+Bˉ1z+B1zˉ+C=0A+Bˉzˉ+Bz+Czˉz=0\begin{aligned} A\frac{1}{z\bar z} + \bar B \frac{1}{z} + B \frac{1}{\bar z} + C = 0 \\ A + \bar B \bar z + B z + C \bar z z = 0 \end{aligned}Azzˉ1​+Bˉz1​+Bzˉ1​+C=0A+Bˉzˉ+Bz+Czˉz=0​

where the coefficients have swapped places, but the equation remains the same. □\square□

Möbius maps preserve the cross-ratio

Definition. Define the cross-ratio between four distinct complex numbers z1,z2,z3,z∈C^z_1, z_2, z_3, z \in \mathbb{\hat C}z1​,z2​,z3​,z∈C^ as the unique Möbius map that maps z1→∞z_1 \to \inftyz1​→∞, z2→0z_2 \to 0z2​→0 and z3→1z_3 \to 1z3​→1 as a function of zzz:

[z1,z2,z3,z]=f(z)=z−z2z−z1⋅z3−z1z3−z2[z_1, z_2, z_3, z] = f(z) = \frac{z - z_2}{z - z_1} \cdot \frac{z_3 - z_1}{z_3 - z_2}[z1​,z2​,z3​,z]=f(z)=z−z1​z−z2​​⋅z3​−z2​z3​−z1​​

which exists uniquely as a result of MMM acting sharply three-transitively on C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^.

Theorem. The cross-ratio [z1,z2,z3,z][z_1, z_2, z_3, z][z1​,z2​,z3​,z] is preserved by a Möbius map: [f(z1),f(z2),f(z3),f(z)]=[z1,z2,z3,z][f(z_1), f(z_2), f(z_3), f(z)] = [z_1, z_2, z_3, z][f(z1​),f(z2​),f(z3​),f(z)]=[z1​,z2​,z3​,z].

Proof.

Let λ=g(z)\lambda = g(z)λ=g(z) be the unique Möbius map that maps z1→∞z_1 \to \inftyz1​→∞, z2→0z_2 \to 0z2​→0, and z3→1z_3 \to 1z3​→1, such that zzz is mapped to λ\lambdaλ under the operation [z1,z2,z3,z][z_1,z_2,z_3,z][z1​,z2​,z3​,z]. Consider the Möbius map formed by gf−1gf^{-1}gf−1, which has

{gf−1(f(z1))=g(z1)=∞gf−1(f(z2))=g(z2)=0gf−1(f(z3))=g(z3)=1gf−1(f(z))=g(z)=λ\begin{cases} gf^{-1}(f(z_1)) = g(z_1) = \infty \\ gf^{-1}(f(z_2)) = g(z_2) = 0 \\ gf^{-1}(f(z_3)) = g(z_3) = 1 \\ gf^{-1}(f(z)) = g(z) = \lambda \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​gf−1(f(z1​))=g(z1​)=∞gf−1(f(z2​))=g(z2​)=0gf−1(f(z3​))=g(z3​)=1gf−1(f(z))=g(z)=λ​

By definition gf−1gf^{-1}gf−1 is the Möbius map formed from the cross-ratio [f(z1),f(z2),f(z3),f(z)][f(z_1), f(z_2), f(z_3), f(z)][f(z1​),f(z2​),f(z3​),f(z)], which means that the cross-ratio evaluates to gf−1(f(z))=g(z)gf^{-1}(f(z)) = g(z)gf−1(f(z))=g(z).

Corollary. There exists a Möbius map that maps from four complex numbers (x1,x2,x3,x4)(x_1, x_2, x_3, x_4)(x1​,x2​,x3​,x4​) to (y1,y2,y3,y4)(y_1, y_2, y_3, y_4)(y1​,y2​,y3​,y4​) if and only if their cross-ratios are equal.

Proof.

First suppose that some f∈Mf \in Mf∈M satisfies f(x1)=y1,f(x2)=y2,f(x3)=y3f(x_1) = y_1, f(x_2) = y_2, f(x_3) = y_3f(x1​)=y1​,f(x2​)=y2​,f(x3​)=y3​, and f(x4)=y4f(x_4) = y_4f(x4​)=y4​. Then we have

[y1,y2,y3,y4]=[f(x1),f(x2),f(x3),f(x4)]=[x1,x2,x3,x4][y_1, y_2, y_3, y_4] = [f(x_1),f(x_2),f(x_3),f(x_4)] =[x_1,x_2,x_3,x_4][y1​,y2​,y3​,y4​]=[f(x1​),f(x2​),f(x3​),f(x4​)]=[x1​,x2​,x3​,x4​]

as cross-ratios are preserved by Möbius maps; and conversely, if

[y1,y2,y3,y4]=[x1,x2,x3,x4][y_1, y_2, y_3, y_4] =[x_1,x_2,x_3,x_4][y1​,y2​,y3​,y4​]=[x1​,x2​,x3​,x4​]

then suppose that f∈Mf \in Mf∈M maps x1→∞x_1 \to \inftyx1​→∞, x2→0x_2 \to 0x2​→0, x3→1x_3 \to 1x3​→1, and x4→λ=f(x4)x_4 \to \lambda = f(x_4)x4​→λ=f(x4​); and g∈Mg \in Mg∈M maps y1→∞y_1 \to \inftyy1​→∞, y2→0y_2 \to 0y2​→0, y3→1y_3 \to 1y3​→1, and y4→g(y4)=f(x4)y_4 \to g(y_4) = f(x_4)y4​→g(y4​)=f(x4​) because the cross-ratios are equal. Thus the function g−1fg^{-1}fg−1f sends x1→y1x_1 \to y_1x1​→y1​, x2→y2x_2 \to y_2x2​→y2​, and x3→y3x_3 \to y_3x3​→y3​; finally, it sends x4→y4x_4 \to y_4x4​→y4​ because

g−1(f(x4))=g−1(g(y4))=y4.g^{-1}(f(x_4)) = g^{-1}(g(y_4)) = y_4.g−1(f(x4​))=g−1(g(y4​))=y4​.

□\square□

And finally, all the players take a bow and scurry off the stage as the curtains fall for our closing act!

Corollary. The four points z1,z2,z3,z4z_1, z_2, z_3, z_4z1​,z2​,z3​,z4​ lie on the same circle or line if and only if their cross-ratio is real.

Proof.

In C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^ - as we alluded to - lines are circles that pass through ∞\infty∞, which is represented by the point (0,0,1)(0,0,1)(0,0,1). We know that any three points lie on the same circle, so without loss of generality, suppose that z1,z2z_1, z_2z1​,z2​ and z3z_3z3​ are on the same circle; further suppose that fff is the unique Möbius map that maps z1→∞z_1 \to \inftyz1​→∞, z2→0z_2 \to 0z2​→0 and z3→1z_3 \to 1z3​→1.

By definition, f(z4)f(z_4)f(z4​) is the cross-ratio [z1,z2,z3,z4][z_1,z_2,z_3,z_4][z1​,z2​,z3​,z4​]. If z4z_4z4​ lies in the same circle as z1z_1z1​, z2z_2z2​ and z3z_3z3​ in C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^, then f(z)f(z)f(z) will lie on the same circle as f(z1),f(z2)f(z_1), f(z_2)f(z1​),f(z2​) and f(z3)f(z_3)f(z3​) (as Möbius maps map circles to circles on the Riemann sphere). As f(z1),f(z2)f(z_1), f(z_2)f(z1​),f(z2​) and f(z3)f(z_3)f(z3​) are ∞,0\infty, 0∞,0 and 111 by construction, and the circle uniquely determined by ∞,0\infty, 0∞,0 and 111 in C^\mathbb{\hat C}C^ is the real axis, f(z4)f(z_4)f(z4​) lies an the real axis and is therefore real.

Conversely, if f(z4)f(z_4)f(z4​) is real, then it lies on the same circle as f(z1)f(z_1)f(z1​), f(z2)f(z_2)f(z2​) and f(z3)f(z_3)f(z3​) - the real axis; the inverse Möbius map f−1f^{-1}f−1, which always exists, also maps a circle to a circle and thus bring z1,z2,z3z_1, z_2, z_3z1​,z2​,z3​ and z4z_4z4​ to the same circle. □\square□
